reviewText: If you work at this consistently and I mean that literally, consistently,  at least five times a week, for five weeks in a row, you might be able to follow the steps.......by that time you might be sick of it.Gin Miller/Reebok has employed a bevy of beauties, perfect young bodies to lead you through this aerobicizing/step workout.  Here, you will do the step, floor, step, floor, move little here, there, change, move, change, move, step, floor....Wow!  With a concept of aerobicizing and step workout, you won't want to do this consistently....there are too many other good videos that offer either.The steps frequently change, cueing isn't the best.  Now, my complaint is that I would rather continue the same steps numerous times rather that constant changing.  I want to feel like I can keep up.  But so many exercise guru doing step workout feel that have to have such variety that it only gets confusing.Music is techno, and the running time is 54 minutes.  If you do this for the entire 54 minutes, you will get a good aerobic workout, but trying to follow the steps is discouraging.  On screen is a scale of numbers that helps you determine how hard you are working, but, there is no determinant to base your level of intensity.Warm-up is 8 minutes, then the workout emerges into several different segments called:  Tribal Fire-Up - 8 min;  Rhythmic Blues - 8 min; Rock Step Pyramid - 8 min;  Vibrant Jazz Medley - 8 min; Total Groove Plateau - 8 min. and a cool-down/stretch 3 min. ...Rizzo
Title: Reebok:Aerostep VHS

reviewText: Gin doesn't give you time to slow down and see what's coming.  Lol, but that's ok.  I like the continued movement - Gin is a great instructor.
Title: Reebok:Aerostep VHS

reviewText: This video is the fourth I've tried from the Reebok series.  Like the others, I found this workout easy to follow and I was able to complete all the moves the first time I popped it in my VCR with no problems.  "Aerostep" is advertised as being "a unique combination of step training and aerobic dance," but the moves are really no different from other step videos I have (basic step, over-the-top, L-step, grapevines, lunges, etc.).The workout is divided into the following parts: Warm-up, Tribal Fire-Up, Rhythmic Blues, Rock Stop Pyramid, Vibrant Jazz Medley, Total Groove Plateau, and Cool-Down/Stretch.  The first four parts are about 8 minutes each while the last three are a little shorter.  When I read the workout breakdown, I was really excited, but they sound cooler than they are.  The movements don't really resemble the high profile titles they are given (except that you do an "A" step movement in part 4 which kind of resembles a pyramid).  The music also does not change much through the different segments.  The changes are rather subtle.  The movements are pretty basic and, whereas Gin Miller's cueing isn't quite as sharp on this video as it is on her other tapes, the workout is very easy to follow.  I think this is a beginners' workout that is even easier than Reebok: The Video.  Basic arm movements are used and there is very little propulsion added by Miller and cast.  It is 45 minutes and is over before you know it. While not as fun as the other Reebok videos, Aerostep is a good beginners' video and a nice "lighter" workout for those who are more advanced.
summary: Not As Cool As The Box Advertises, But Still Good
Title: Reebok:Aerostep VHS

reviewText: This was an enjoyable video...challenging, but not very difficult. My only problem was that sometimes her cueing was off. When introducing a new move, she just went into it before really saying anything, so I was kind of caught off guard. But other than that, it's an excellent step video and a great workout! You'll definitely sweat a little and get your heart rate up!!
Title: Reebok:Aerostep VHS

reviewText: I like this workout so much I have 2 copies of it. It is a combination of step moves and aerobic dance, I myself would rate it intermediate. I consider myself to be an intermediate exerciser and there are some moves that may take a couple tries to get, but it isn't hard to follow at all. Lots of fun combinations and fun moves, there are ponies, mambos, a fun one that Gin calls "The Caveman", then you have your basic, turn steps, A steps, over the tops etc. I like Gin as an instructor, she seems to be having fun in this workout as do the background exercisers. Not a hard workout, some might even think it is way too easy for them, but I always seem to get a good workout from it. Get yourself a copy if you can find one. I just wish it was on DVD.
Title: Reebok:Aerostep VHS
